message: I would prefer not to have to update requirements.txt every time.  Any ideas on how to update each time?

When I run an "epio upload" it properly pulls the repository.  However when I modify that repository to add e.g. a new setuptools dependency, or something that affects INSTALLED_APPS, and rerun "epio upload", it does not pull the latest version of that repo.

If I change it to a hash, e.g.:
-e git+https://github.com/username/project-name@e9d978e#egg=projectname
then it will pull that specific version, and I'll get the changes I expected.

I have a line in my requirements.txt
-e git+https://github.com/username/project-name@master#egg=projectname
ep.io caches the package it downloads for a day or so, so either you need to change that hash or wait a day.
Yep, as liorsion says, there's caching in place, it's what makes most uploads so fast
the best solution is probably a "no cache" flag of some kind, I'll look into implementing one that won't confuse pip if you run the file locally

@andrewgodwin, thank you.  i'm happy about the caching in general, as it indeed helps with upload speed.  i'll look forward to a no-cache flag if you implement one, but i think i may also look into a scripted approach to updating hashes locally.  explicit better than implicit and all that.  :)
Here is a first pass at the script I'm going to use to manage my requirements.txt file based on the state of sibling repos: https://gist.github.com/983536/0c17610ae4b3d66b22b8fc731d5dbe1576b6e7b1
@gldnspud Yes, in a way, freezing the hashes are better as it guarantees exact redeployability of the requirements, on ep.io or elsewhere.
